body:
So you're passing an array-like value to `by`, and it seems like the title is using the `by` value as part of the title and xlabel hence why you are seeing the array repr cloud the plot.

I think it's reasonable to suppress array inputs from being included in the supporting plot text, but what would be a suitable alternative label (maybe we just don't include a label)?

cc @TomAugspurger 

FYI, to get a better looking plot, create a new `'month'` column and then specify `by='month'` in the boxplot

```
df['month'] = df['date'].dt.month
df.boxplot(column='value', by='month')
```

Thanks for the response, @mroeschke !

> I think it's reasonable to suppress array inputs from being included in the supporting plot text, but what would be a suitable alternative label (maybe we just don't include a label)?

In my opinion, not including a label would be a better choice for situations like this. 

I think that this issue happens because the behavior of dataframe.boxplot() is different from other plotting functions such as dataframe.hist() if by= is specified. For instance, dataframe.boxplot() draws a one plot with multiple boxplots grouped by the values in a column stated with by= option. On the other hand, dataframe.hist() draws multiple, independent histograms grouped by the values in a column stated with by= option.

> FYI, to get a better looking plot, create a new `'month'` column and then specify `by='month'` in the boxplot
> 
> ```
> df['month'] = df['date'].dt.month
> df.boxplot(column='value', by='month')
> ```

Yes, I am currently circumventing this issue by creating new columns dedicated to month/year/day/etc.


By the way, I am still confused about why dataframe.hist() and dataframe.plot.hist() show different behaviors compared to dataframe.boxplot() with respect to by=df['date'].dt.month or other datetime functions. Is this just another bug or an intended design?

For example, the following code works fine without any issue although it draws multiple plots of histograms instead of one plot with multiple histograms.
```
df.hist(column='value',by=df['date'].dt.month)
```
![untitled](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43888085/46565768-f0856300-c945-11e8-855a-1d9d91934c68.png)

However, if I use dataframe.plot.hist to the same job, it returns a non-grouped result
= identical to the result of df['value'].plot.hist() or df.hist(column='value')
```
df['value'].plot.hist(by=df['date'].dt.month)
```
![index](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43888085/46565902-1a3f8980-c948-11e8-9b41-f4048d66d64c.png)

The docstring for `DataFrame.hist` states:


> A histogram is a representation of the distribution of data. This function calls matplotlib.pyplot.hist(), on each series in the DataFrame, resulting in one histogram per column

So in that case you'll get one plot per column _per group_

As opposed to `df['value']` which is a series, so it will just produce one plot since the base data is 1D

@mroeschke , thanks again for the clarification.

 I am still curious about why the result of `df['value'].hist(by=df['date'].dt.month)` is different from `df['value'].plot.hist(by=df['date'].dt.month)`, but this is not relevant to the topic anymore.
I think `by=array` should essentially behave the same as assigning that array to a column and taking passing the column name to `by`.
